-Facility floor plans and piping & instrumentation diagrams.

5.0 PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION AND PREVENTION PROGRAM

The Occupational Safety and Health Administration¿s (OSHA) requirements under ¿Process Safety Management of Hazardous Materials¿, Code of Federal Regulations Title 29 Part 1910.119 (29 CFR 1910.119,) also meet the EPA¿s ¿Prevention Program¿ requirements.  


?	Employee Participation-   Access to the RMP/PSM Manual is available through the Plant Engineering Manager.  This RMP/PSM Manual and the documents must be controlled documents:

-	No documents should be removed without approval by Plant Engineering Manager.
-	Original copies of documentation may not be removed from the file area.
-	No marking should be made on original documents unless approved by the Plant Engineering Manager.
-	New documents may not be added without approval from the Plant Engineering Manager.

?	Emergency Program ¿ Employees with leadership or technical roles in the Emergency Action Plan or emergency procedures, such as the Emergency Isolation and Shutdown SOP, are encouraged to suggest improvements at any time, including during emergency related training.

?	Process Safety Information (PSI) ¿ The team gathering and reviewing the PSI and conducting the PHA included must include a non supervisory employee (or their representative.)  

?	Process Hazard Analysis- ConAgra has conducted a PHA during November, 2008. ConAgra updates a site-specific PHA program at a minimum of five (5) years and whenever a change is significant to require a change in PSI. The PHA was conducted using ¿What if¿ technique.

?	Operating Procedures ¿ The most recent review of SOPs   was completed on January 8, 2006. If at any time an employee has a question regarding the safety of completing a task described in a Standard Operating Procedure (SOP), they should stop work and seek an answer from the Plant Engineering Manager. Employees are encouraged to suggest SOP improveme

Risk Management Progarm
ConAgra  Foods     
4300 West 62 nd St
Indianapolis, IN  
                                                                                                                                                          
1.0INTRODUCTIONS                                                                                                                                                               In 1990, the Clean Air Act (CAA) was amended to prevent accidental releases of toxic and flammable chemicals.  Section 112 ® of the CAA required the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to issue a rule.  EPAs rule went beyond OSHA¿s PSM in intent by requiring the intent of these provisions was to identify potential impacts to public and environmental receptors. The Rule¿s ¿Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions¿, published in Title 40, Part 68 of the Code of Federal Regulations (40 CFR Part 68) apply to a wide variety of facilities that handle, store, manufacture, or use toxic substances.  This rule requires that covered facilities develop and implement a risk management program.  The risk management program also incorporates the OSHA PSM program. 
The Facility is classified as Program 3 and therefore is subject to the following program elements:

-An overall management system to supervise the implementation of the program,
-An offsite consequence analysis that evaluates specific potential worst-case and alternative release scenarios,
-A 5-year history of regulated accidental substance releases from covered processes,
-An integrated prevention program to manage risk, consisting of 12 elements.  These 12 elements are essentially identical to those defined under OSHA PSM (trade secrets are not applicable to refrigeration, and emergency response is covered separately).                                                                                                                                                                         - An emergency

response program, and
-A risk management plan (RMP), revised at least once every five years that summarizes and documents these activities for all covered processes.  The RMP is the summary document submitted to the EPA.

2.0 OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

The offsite consequence analysis (OCA) consisted of evaluating a worst-case release scenario and an alternative release scenario.  The methods used to calculate a distance to toxic endpoint for both the worst-case and alternative release scenarios are presented in EPA¿s Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration (EPA 550-B-98-014).  Results were verified using the EPA software RMP*Comp version 1.06.  The toxic endpoint for ammonia is 0.14 milligrams per liter (200 ppm) ambient concentration in air.
2.1 Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios 
The EPA requires that failure of the largest vessel at full capacity be evaluated as the worst-case release scenario.  Administrative controls for ammonia inventory may be considered.  The high-pressure receiver (HPR) is the largest vessel in the ARS at the Facility.  The anticipated charge of ammonia to the ARS is 45,705 pounds. The largest vessel is High Pressure Receiver (HPR). Maximum liquid anhydrous ammonia in the HPR can be stored at 80% of the full capacity.  17,800 pounds of ammonia in the HPR will be used as the release quantity for the worst-case release scenario.   The release is assumed to occur in ten minutes, in accordance with the methodology prescribed in 40 CFR 68.25.  Since the HPR is located indoors, a mitigated release was run. 
The distance to toxic endpoint for the worst-case scenario involving a liquid ammonia release from the refrigeration system is calculated at 1.7 miles.  The formula used to calculate the worst-case scenario distance is presented in EPA¿s Risk RMP*COMP for Ammonia Refrigeration Systems, Appendix 4B.  Model assumptions include an urban release (obstacles present) and no mitigation (release occurred outdoors). Th

e results of the selected alternative release scenario were verified with RMP-Comp software, version 1.07.  
2.2 The ALTERNATE RELEASE SCENARIO evaluated was a leak from an air unit.  The scenario assumes a 1/4-inch diameter hole in the air unit that took 10 minutes to isolate.  Pressure within the air unit was assumed to be 100 pounds per square inch gauge (psig).  Based on EPA¿s RMP*Comp software, the alternative scenario would result in a release of 1,000 pounds of ammonia over 10 minutes. The distance to toxic endpoint for the alternative release scenario selected is 0.1 miles.  Model assumptions include an urban release (obstacles present) and no mitigation (release occurred outdoors).  The formula used to calculate the alternative scenario distance is presented in EPA¿s RMP*COMP  for Ammonia Refrigeration Systems. The results of the selected alternative release scenario were verified with RMP-Comp software, version 1.07.  
 
2.3 OFFSITE IMPACTS

40 CFR 68 requires that the area within the worst-case and alternative release zones (within a circle with a center at the point of the release and a radius determined by the distance to the endpoint) be evaluated for off-site impacts, including: 

-Estimated residential population (rounded to two significant figures)
-Public receptors including: residences; schools; hospitals; correctional facilities; recreation areas; and commercial, office, or industrial areas 
-Environmental receptors including: national or state parks, forests or monuments; officially designated wildlife sanctuaries, preserves, or refuges; and federal wilderness areas
Land view Software using 1990 US Census data were considered for Worst-Case and Alternate Release Scenarios.

3.0 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The five-year accident history that must be included in the risk management program manual and the RMP submittal includes only releases of ammonia that meet the following criteria.
-On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage, or

-Known off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evaluations, or sheltering in place
-The release must be from a regulated process, in other words a process using a regulated substance above its threshold quantity.  (EPA RMP Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration, Revised May 2000.)

No accidental releases involving ammonia that meet the above criteria have occurred in the last five years.  

4.0 EMERGENCY PROGRAM

Facilities that have at least one Program 2 or Program 3 process, including this facility, must implement an emergency program to protect employees, the nearby public, and the environment.  The regulatory requirements that apply to a facility¿s emergency program are determined by whether the facility will respond to a release of a regulated substance.  The definition of ¿response¿ under the Rule does not include:
-actions conducted at the time of release by employees in the immediate area of the spill,
-actions by employees who remain to operate or shutdown critical plant systems, and
-Releases where there is no potential safety or health hazard.

ConAgra Foods intends to use the services of external emergency responders in the event of an anhydrous ammonia release, and ConAgra Foods employees will not carry out actions that constitute a ¿response¿ by the OSHA definition.  Therefore, ConAgra Foods has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP).

The EAP includes:
-Emergency Coordinator list ¿ indicating on-call and backup employees 
-Procedures for employee evacuation and floor plans with escape routes
-Procedures for outside responder notification
-Procedures for using, inspecting, testing, and maintaining emergency action equipment, such as alarms, loudspeakers/PA systems, two-way radios, wind socks, flash lights, etc.

The EAP also references the following documents, which are intended to facilitate release mitigation by ConAgra Foods employees and emergency response by outside organizations:

-Emergency Isolation and Shutdown SOP for

nts to the Plant Engineering Manager at any time, particularly after using or being trained on an SOP.  Experience from prior employment or experience gained while implementing SOPs is highly valued by ConAgra Foods.

?	Training ¿ ConAgra provides class room training on SOPs, Preventative Maintenance, Confined Space, Lockout/Tagout, Line Breaking, and Hotwork on annual basis. Employees are encouraged to provide input regarding the adequacy and quality of any training they received, both during and after the training.  Furthermore, employees are encouraged to suggest additional training for themselves or others to the Plant Engineering Manager.

?	Pre-Startup Safety Review ¿ The date of the most recent pre-startup review was conducted on August 31, 2008. Maintenance employees will be given time to ¿shadow¿ the ammonia refrigeration mechanical contractor¿s startup crew.  Employees should alert the Plant Engineering Manager to any safety concerns or other suggests they have at any time before or after startup.

?	Incident Investigation ¿ The date of most the most recent Incident Investigation was performed on November 9, 2008.  Employees involved in any incident or near miss regarding ammonia will part of the incident investigation team.

?	Management of Change- The most recent Management of Change procedure was used on August 31, 2008. The ConAgra Facility has established a Management of Change (MOC) procedure.  The purpose of MOC is to prevent changes in the process or procedures from being implemented without securing the appropriate review and approvals. The goal of a MOC program is to ensure that changes will not result in undetected unsafe conditions and that employees will be aware of all changes and their implications. 
?	Compliance Audit- The date of most recent compliance audit was conducted on March 12, 2007. Compliance with the Risk Management and PSM Program requirements must be audited at least every three years.  The compliance audit must be conducted by

at least one person knowledgeable in ammonia refrigeration system.  
?	Mechanical Integrity- The Chief Engineer has overall responsibility for the Mechanical Integrity program.  Written procedures must be prepared and implemented to maintain the integrity of the following process equipment.
-	Pressure vessels and storage tanks,
-	Piping systems (including piping components such as valves);
-	Relief and vent systems and devices;
-	Emergency shutdown systems, including isolation valves
-	Controls (including monitoring devices and sensors, alarms, and interlocks) and,
-	Pumps



?	Hot Work Permits- When conducting hot work operations (i.e., welding, cutting, brazing) on or near the covered process, process piping, or other associated equipment containing anhydrous ammonia, an internal Hot Work Permit in accordance with 29 CFR 1910.252 (a) must be issued, authorized, and reviewed.  The issuance of a Hot Work Permit must be completed prior to the start of the covered hot work operation.
?	Contractor Qualifications- The PSM standard applies to contractors performing maintenance or repair, turnaround, major renovation or specialty work on or adjacent to the ARS. It does not apply to contractors providing incidental services that do not influence process safety, such as janitorial, food services, laundry, or delivery.  The purpose of the Contractor Program is to ensure that contractors are selected based on their safety performance and programs, that they have been informed of process hazards, procedures and practices, and that they are periodically evaluated.  This PSM requirement places responsibilities on both the ConAgra Foods management and the contract employers.
